questions.question: A primary tax advantage of S corporation status over C corporation status is:

options.B: Avoidance of double taxation on corporate income
options.C: Lower tax rates on business income
options.D: Ability to issue multiple classes of stock

questions.explanation: S corporations are pass-through entities where income is taxed only at the shareholder level, avoiding the double taxation that occurs with C corporations (corporate tax plus shareholder dividend tax). S corps have shareholder limits (100), one class of stock requirement, and use individual (not corporate) tax rates.
questions.tip: S corp = single level of tax (pass-through). C corp = potential double tax (corporate + dividend).

questions.question: The maximum number of shareholders an S corporation may have is:
questions.explanation: An S corporation may have no more than 100 shareholders. Family members (within six generations of a common ancestor) can elect to be treated as a single shareholder for this purpose. Exceeding the limit terminates the S election.
questions.tip: S corp = 100 shareholder max. Family members can elect to count as one shareholder.

questions.question: Which of the following may NOT be a shareholder of an S corporation?

options.B: Grantor trust
options.C: Partnership

questions.explanation: S corporation shareholders must be individuals (U.S. citizens or residents), estates, certain trusts (grantor trusts, QSSTs, ESBTs), and certain tax-exempt organizations. Partnerships, corporations, and nonresident aliens cannot be S corporation shareholders.
questions.tip: S corp shareholders: individuals, estates, certain trusts. NOT partnerships, corporations, or nonresident aliens.

questions.question: An S corporation shareholder-employee must receive:

options.B: Reasonable compensation for services performed
options.C: At least 50% of the corporation's net income as salary

questions.explanation: Shareholder-employees who perform services for an S corporation must receive reasonable compensation (salary subject to employment taxes) before taking distributions. The IRS may recharacterize distributions as wages if no reasonable salary is paid, resulting in back taxes and penalties.
questions.tip: S corp owner-employees: must pay reasonable salary first. Can't take all income as distributions to avoid payroll tax.

questions.question: The one class of stock requirement for S corporations means:

options.A: The corporation can only issue common stock
options.B: All outstanding shares must have identical distribution and liquidation rights
options.C: Shareholders cannot have different voting rights
options.D: Stock cannot be transferred to new shareholders

questions.explanation: S corporations may have only one class of stock, meaning all shares must have identical rights to distribution and liquidation proceeds. However, voting rights may differ (voting and non-voting common stock is permitted). Differences in distribution rights would create a second class of stock.
questions.tip: One class = identical distribution and liquidation rights. Voting rights CAN differ.

questions.question: To be effective for the current tax year, Form 2553 (S corporation election) must be filed by:

options.A: The 15th day of the 2nd month of the tax year
options.B: The 15th day of the 3rd month of the tax year
options.C: The due date of the tax return for that year

questions.explanation: To be effective for the current tax year, Form 2553 must be filed by the 15th day of the 3rd month of the tax year (March 15 for calendar-year corporations). If filed later, the election is effective for the following tax year. Late election relief may be available under Rev. Proc. 2013-30.
questions.tip: S election deadline: March 15 for calendar year corps (2½ months into year). Late = effective next year.

questions.question: An S corporation shareholder's stock basis is increased by:

options.B: The shareholder's share of separately and nonseparately stated income
options.C: The shareholder's share of nondeductible expenses

questions.explanation: Stock basis increases for the shareholder's share of income (both separately stated items and nonseparately computed income) and additional capital contributions. Basis decreases for distributions, nondeductible expenses, and losses. Proper basis tracking is essential for determining loss deductibility and distribution taxation.
questions.tip: S corp basis increases: income, contributions. Decreases: distributions, losses, nondeductible expenses.

questions.question: When an S corporation with accumulated E&P makes a distribution, the distribution is treated as coming from (in order):

options.B: AAA first, then E&P, then other adjustments account
options.C: Stock basis first, then AAA

questions.explanation: Distributions from an S corporation with accumulated E&P (from prior C corp years) come first from AAA (tax-free to extent of basis), then from accumulated E&P (taxable dividend), then from the other adjustments account, and finally from remaining stock basis. An election can be made to distribute E&P first.
questions.tip: S corp with E&P: AAA first (tax-free), then E&P (dividend), then OAA, then basis.

questions.question: An S corporation shareholder obtains debt basis from:

options.B: Direct loans from the shareholder to the corporation
options.C: Shareholder guarantees of corporate debt

questions.explanation: Debt basis in an S corporation comes only from direct loans from the shareholder to the corporation. Unlike partnerships, guarantees of corporate debt and back-to-back loans generally do not create basis. Debt basis allows loss deductions after stock basis is exhausted.
questions.tip: S corp debt basis = direct shareholder loans only. Guarantees don't count (unlike partnerships).

questions.question: S corporation distributions (not compensation) to shareholder-employees are:

options.B: Subject to FICA and FUTA taxes
options.C: Not subject to employment taxes

questions.explanation: S corporation distributions are not subject to self-employment tax or FICA/FUTA taxes. Only wages paid to shareholder-employees are subject to employment taxes. This creates a planning opportunity but also IRS scrutiny of unreasonably low salaries designed to avoid employment taxes.
questions.tip: S corp advantage: distributions avoid employment tax. But salary must be reasonable - can't minimize to avoid taxes.

questions.question: The built-in gains tax applies to S corporations that:

options.B: Converted from C corporation status and sell appreciated assets within the recognition period
options.C: Receive contributions of appreciated property

questions.explanation: The built-in gains (BIG) tax applies when a C corporation converts to S status and sells assets with built-in gains within the recognition period (currently 5 years). The tax is at the highest corporate rate (21%) on the net recognized built-in gain, limited to the built-in gain at conversion.
questions.tip: BIG tax = corporate-level tax on appreciated assets sold within 5 years of C-to-S conversion.

questions.question: An S corporation with accumulated E&P may be subject to the excess passive income tax if passive investment income exceeds what percentage of gross receipts?
questions.explanation: S corporations with accumulated E&P (from C corp years) are subject to a corporate-level tax on excess net passive income if passive investment income exceeds 25% of gross receipts. If this occurs for three consecutive years, the S election automatically terminates.
questions.tip: Excess passive income: >25% passive + accumulated E&P = corporate tax. 3 consecutive years = S termination.

questions.question: S corporation shareholders claim the Section 199A QBI deduction:

options.A: At the corporate level on Form 1120-S
options.B: On their individual returns based on their share of qualified business income
options.C: Only if the corporation has more than 100 employees
options.D: As a deduction against wages received

questions.explanation: The Section 199A QBI deduction is claimed by shareholders on their individual returns, not at the corporate level. The S corporation reports each shareholder's share of QBI, W-2 wages, and UBIA on Schedule K-1. Shareholders then compute their deduction subject to individual income limitations.
questions.tip: QBI deduction is individual-level. S corp provides info on K-1; shareholder calculates deduction on personal return.

questions.question: Health insurance premiums paid by an S corporation for a more-than-2% shareholder-employee are:

options.B: Included in the shareholder's W-2 wages but deductible above-the-line by the shareholder
options.C: Deductible by the corporation but taxable as a dividend
options.D: Not deductible by either the corporation or shareholder

questions.explanation: Health insurance premiums paid for more-than-2% S corp shareholder-employees must be included in the shareholder's W-2 (Box 1, not subject to FICA). The shareholder can then deduct the amount above-the-line on their personal return (self-employed health insurance deduction). This differs from C corp treatment.
questions.tip: >2% S corp shareholder health insurance: reported on W-2, then deducted by shareholder. Net effect similar to sole proprietor.

questions.question: To voluntarily revoke an S corporation election, shareholders owning more than what percentage of shares must consent?
questions.explanation: Voluntary revocation of an S election requires consent from shareholders owning more than 50% of the outstanding shares (voting and nonvoting). The revocation can specify a future effective date; otherwise, it's effective at the beginning of the following tax year if filed after the 15th day of the 3rd month.
questions.tip: S revocation requires >50% shareholder consent. Can specify effective date.

questions.question: When an S corporation distribution exceeds the shareholder's stock basis:

options.A: The entire distribution is taxable as ordinary income
options.B: The excess is taxable as capital gain
options.C: The excess creates a negative basis
options.D: The distribution is returned to the corporation

questions.explanation: Distributions exceeding stock basis (for an S corp without accumulated E&P) are treated as gain from the sale of stock - typically long-term capital gain if the stock has been held more than one year. Stock basis cannot go below zero; excess distributions generate capital gain.
questions.tip: S corp distribution > basis = capital gain (sale treatment). Basis can't go negative.

questions.question: S corporation losses that exceed the shareholder's basis are:

options.B: Carried forward indefinitely until basis is restored
options.C: Converted to capital losses

questions.explanation: S corporation losses exceeding the shareholder's basis (stock plus debt basis) are suspended and carried forward indefinitely until sufficient basis is restored. Basis can be restored through additional capital contributions, loans to the corporation, or allocation of future income.
questions.tip: Suspended S corp losses: carried forward indefinitely, deductible when basis is restored.

questions.question: An S corporation is generally required to use:

options.A: Any fiscal year selected by the shareholders
options.B: A calendar year (with limited exceptions)
options.C: The tax year of its majority shareholder
options.D: The same year as its parent corporation

questions.explanation: S corporations must generally use a calendar year unless they can establish a business purpose for a different year or elect a fiscal year under Section 444 (which requires a deposit payment to compensate for deferral). This prevents deferral of shareholder income recognition.
questions.tip: S corps = calendar year required (generally). Section 444 fiscal year election requires deposit payment.

questions.question: Which of the following must be separately stated on an S corporation's Schedule K-1?

options.B: Depreciation on business assets
options.C: Charitable contributions

questions.explanation: Items that could affect shareholders' tax liability differently (based on individual circumstances) must be separately stated. These include charitable contributions, capital gains/losses, Section 1231 gains/losses, tax-exempt income, investment interest, foreign taxes, and rental activities. Items like COGS and business depreciation are part of ordinary income.
questions.tip: Separately stated = items affecting shareholders differently. Charitable, capital gains, Section 1231, tax-exempt income, etc.

questions.question: If an S corporation election is inadvertently terminated, the IRS may:

options.B: Grant relief if the terminating event is corrected and shareholders agree to adjustments
options.C: Automatically restore the election after one year
options.D: Only restore the election if no taxes were avoided

questions.explanation: Under Section 1362(f), the IRS may grant inadvertent termination relief if: (1) the termination was inadvertent, (2) steps are taken to correct the terminating event within a reasonable time, and (3) the corporation and shareholders agree to any adjustments required by the IRS.
questions.tip: Inadvertent termination relief available if corrected quickly and adjustments accepted. Apply via PLR.

questions.question: S corporation shareholder-employees participating in company retirement plans:

options.A: Are treated the same as C corporation shareholder-employees
options.B: Cannot participate in any qualified retirement plans
options.C: Are treated similarly to sole proprietors for contribution limit purposes

questions.explanation: S corporation shareholder-employees are treated the same as C corporation shareholder-employees for qualified retirement plan purposes. They can participate in 401(k) plans, receive employer matching, and are subject to the same contribution limits. This differs from the health insurance treatment.
questions.tip: S corp retirement plans = same as C corp. Full participation allowed. Different from health insurance treatment.

questions.question: The correct order for adjusting S corporation stock basis is:

options.B: Income, nondeductible expenses, losses, distributions
options.C: Income, losses, distributions, nondeductible expenses

questions.explanation: Stock basis is adjusted in this order: (1) increased for income items, (2) decreased for nondeductible, noncapital expenses (like 50% meals, penalties), (3) decreased for deductible losses and deductions, (4) decreased for distributions. This ordering can affect loss deductibility.
questions.tip: Basis order: +income, -nondeductible expenses, -losses, -distributions. Order matters for loss limitation.

questions.question: Net unrealized built-in gain (NUBIG) at S election is calculated as:

options.A: FMV of assets minus basis of assets
options.B: FMV of assets minus basis of assets, minus liabilities
options.C: FMV of assets minus basis of assets, including any built-in loss items

questions.explanation: NUBIG equals the excess of FMV of assets over their adjusted basis at the S election date, but is reduced by built-in loss assets and built-in deduction items (like accounts receivable for cash basis, depreciation adjustments). NUBIG caps the total built-in gains tax exposure over the recognition period.
questions.tip: NUBIG = FMV - basis of all assets (net of built-in losses). This caps total BIG tax exposure.

questions.question: An electing small business trust (ESBT) holding S corporation stock is taxed on its S corporation income at:

options.B: The highest individual marginal rate
options.C: Capital gains rates only

questions.explanation: The S corporation income portion of an ESBT is taxed at the highest individual marginal rate (currently 37%) at the trust level, regardless of the trust's other income or distributions to beneficiaries. This is separate from the trust's other income, which is taxed normally. QBI deduction may apply.
questions.tip: ESBT S corp income = taxed at highest individual rate (37%) at trust level. Separate from other trust income.

questions.question: After an S election is revoked or terminated, the corporation generally cannot re-elect S status for:

options.B: 3 years
options.C: 5 years

questions.explanation: After revocation or termination, a corporation cannot make a new S election for 5 years without IRS consent. The IRS may consent to an earlier re-election if: (1) more than 50% ownership has changed, or (2) the event causing termination was not reasonably within the corporation's control.
questions.tip: S election terminated → 5-year waiting period. IRS may consent to earlier re-election in certain circumstances.

questions.question: The accumulated adjustments account (AAA) differs from stock basis in that AAA:

options.B: Is increased by tax-exempt income
options.C: Is a corporate-level account, not shareholder-level
options.D: Is not reduced by nondeductible expenses

questions.explanation: AAA is a corporate-level account tracking undistributed S corp income that has been taxed to shareholders. Stock basis is shareholder-level. AAA can go negative from losses; it's not reduced by tax-exempt income (unlike basis) but is reduced by nondeductible expenses and distributions.
questions.tip: AAA = corporate account (same for all shareholders). Basis = individual shareholder account. AAA can go negative.

questions.question: IRS factors for determining reasonable S corporation shareholder-employee compensation include all of the following EXCEPT:

options.A: Training and experience of the employee
options.B: Comparable compensation in similar businesses
options.C: The amount of distributions the shareholder desires

questions.explanation: The IRS considers factors like duties performed, training, experience, time and effort devoted, comparable compensation in similar businesses, dividend history, and economic conditions. The shareholder's desired distribution level is irrelevant - compensation must be objectively reasonable regardless of preferences.
questions.tip: Reasonable compensation based on job duties, experience, comparables, time devoted. Not on what shareholder wants.

questions.question: A qualified subchapter S trust (QSST) must meet all of the following requirements EXCEPT:

options.A: All income must be distributed currently to one individual beneficiary
options.B: The trust may have multiple current income beneficiaries
options.C: Principal may only be distributed to the current income beneficiary
options.D: The income beneficiary's interest must terminate upon the earlier of death or trust termination

questions.explanation: A QSST must have exactly one current income beneficiary who receives all income currently. Principal distributions are limited to that beneficiary. The beneficiary's income interest must terminate at death or trust termination. Having multiple current income beneficiaries disqualifies QSST status.
questions.tip: QSST = single current beneficiary, all income distributed currently. Multiple beneficiaries → use ESBT instead.

questions.question: For purposes of the at-risk rules, an S corporation shareholder's at-risk amount generally equals:

options.B: Stock basis plus debt basis
options.C: Stock basis plus debt basis plus share of nonrecourse debt
options.D: Stock basis plus loans for which shareholder is personally liable

questions.explanation: A shareholder's at-risk amount in an S corporation includes stock basis plus amounts borrowed for which the shareholder is personally liable or has pledged property (other than the S corp interest) as security. Unlike partnerships, S corp shareholders generally cannot include nonrecourse debt in their at-risk amount.
questions.tip: At-risk in S corp = basis + personal liability debt. More restrictive than partnership at-risk rules.

questions.question: When converting from C to S corporation status, the optimal timing considers:

options.A: Converting when assets have maximum appreciation
options.B: Converting when the corporation has substantial accumulated E&P
options.C: Converting when built-in gains are minimal or assets have declined in value
options.D: Converting immediately before a planned sale of appreciated assets

questions.explanation: Optimal C-to-S conversion timing minimizes built-in gains exposure by converting when asset values are low relative to basis (minimal appreciation or depreciation). Converting before a planned asset sale triggers BIG tax. Accumulated E&P creates passive income concerns. Conversion during asset depressions reduces tax exposure.
questions.tip: C-to-S conversion: best when assets have minimal built-in gain. Avoid converting before planned asset sales.

questions.question: An S corporation with accumulated E&P may elect to distribute E&P before AAA by:

options.B: Making a deemed dividend election on the return
options.C: Distributing property instead of cash
options.D: Having shareholders consent and making the election with a timely filed return

questions.explanation: An S corporation can elect to treat distributions as coming from accumulated E&P first (bypassing AAA) by making the election on a timely filed return with shareholder consent. This may be desirable to purge E&P and eliminate passive income concerns, even though it creates taxable dividends.
questions.tip: E&P bypass election: purge E&P intentionally to avoid passive income issues. Requires shareholder consent.

questions.question: The correct order for applying loss limitations to S corporation losses is:

options.A: Basis, at-risk, passive activity, excess business loss
options.B: At-risk, basis, passive activity, excess business loss
options.C: Passive activity, at-risk, basis, excess business loss
options.D: Basis, passive activity, at-risk, excess business loss

questions.explanation: S corporation losses are subject to limitations in this order: (1) basis limitation, (2) at-risk limitation, (3) passive activity limitation, (4) excess business loss limitation. Losses must pass each hurdle before being deductible. Suspended losses at each level carry forward separately.
questions.tip: Loss limitation order: Basis → At-risk → Passive → Excess business loss. Each creates separate carryforward.

questions.question: Under the open account debt rules, shareholder advances to an S corporation:

options.A: Are always treated as equity contributions
options.B: May be treated as a single debt for basis purposes if properly structured
options.C: Never provide debt basis
options.D: Must be evidenced by formal promissory notes

questions.explanation: The open account debt rules (post-2014) allow shareholders to treat advances and repayments during the year as net increases or decreases to a single open account debt balance, rather than tracing each advance. The net increase at year-end provides debt basis; net decrease triggers gain. Maximum $25,000 threshold applies.
questions.tip: Open account debt: net advances/repayments during year, simplifies tracking. $25K threshold for special treatment.

questions.question: The built-in gains tax can be reduced or avoided by:

options.B: Using installment sale reporting for pre-conversion assets
options.C: Waiting until after the recognition period to sell appreciated assets

questions.explanation: The most straightforward way to avoid BIG tax is to wait until after the 5-year recognition period to sell appreciated assets. Other strategies include using NOL carryforwards to offset recognized built-in gains, contributing assets with built-in losses, or electing S status when asset values are depressed.
questions.tip: BIG tax avoidance: wait 5 years, use NOLs, convert when values are low. Installment sales don't defer BIG tax.

questions.question: An S corporation may be preferable to an LLC taxed as a partnership when:

options.A: Owners want maximum flexibility in allocating income and losses
options.B: The business expects significant losses that should flow through to owners
options.C: Owner-employees want to minimize self-employment taxes on business profits
options.D: The business plans to raise capital from foreign investors

questions.explanation: S corporations are advantageous when owners want to minimize employment taxes because distributions (beyond reasonable salary) are not subject to self-employment or FICA taxes. LLCs allow flexible allocations and can have foreign/entity owners. Loss pass-through is more limited in S corps due to stricter basis rules.
questions.tip: S corp advantage: employment tax savings on distributions. LLC advantage: flexibility, no ownership restrictions, easier loss pass-through.
